‚Ä¢If you are a tourist, familiarize yourself with local tsunami evacuation protocols...

‚Ä¢It is vital to familiarize yourself with tsunami notification information: Tsunami Watch, Tsunami Warning, Tsunami Warning.

Visit http://www.ready.gov/tsunamis for more information.

‚Ä¢Create a family communications plan to know how you‚Äôll contact each other & reconnect if separated. Establish a family meeting place that‚Äôs familiar & easy to find.   
‚Ä¢Build an emergency kit to ensure you and your family are prepared to be on your own for at least 72 hours.

‚Ä¢Create and practice an evacuation plan with your family. If you live in a tsunami evacuation zone you will find signs in your community. Familiarity may save your life. Be able to follow your escape route at night and during inclement weather.
FEMA encourages citizens to protect themselves and their families by taking the following steps to ensure they are ready in the event of a tsunami:

If a major earthquake or landslide occurs close to shore, areas are at greater risk if they are less than 25 feet above sea level and within a mile of the shoreline. The first wave in a series could reach the beach in a few minutes, even before a warning is issued.

According to the National Oceanic & Atmospheric Administration, tsunamis are one of the most powerful & destructive natural forces, delivering a series of extremely long waves which can cause dangerous coastal flooding & powerful currents that can last for several hours or days.

Following an intense earthquake that occurred in the Gulf of Alaska, which prompted tsunami watches, advisories and warnings across many state coastlines, FEMA continues to highlight safety tips for those who live in or visit coastal communities.
